conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the acceleration-time graph to determine when the velocity is at its maximum by integrating the acceleration over time.

The image shows an acceleration-time graph for a body moving along a straight line. The acceleration starts at 2 m/s² at time t = 0, remains constant until t = 2 s, and then decreases linearly to 0 m/s² at t = 4 s.

premise: The acceleration is 2 m/s² from t = 0 to t = 2 s.
conclusion: The area under the acceleration curve from t = 0 to t = 2 s can be calculated using the formula for the area of a rectangle: \(2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \times 2 \, \text{s} = 4 \, \text{m/s}\).
From t = 2 s to t = 4 s, the acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s².

premise: From t = 2 s to t = 4 s, the acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s².
conclusion: Calculate the area under the acceleration curve from t = 2 s to t = 4 s using the formula for the area of a triangle: \(\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \times 2 \, \text{s} = 2 \, \text{m/s}\).

premise: The areas under the acceleration curve from t = 0 to t = 2 s and from t = 2 s to t = 4 s are 4 m/s and 2 m/s respectively.
conclusion: The total change in velocity from t = 0 to t = 4 s is the sum of these areas: \(4 \, \text{m/s} + 2 \, \text{m/s} = 6 \, \text{m/s}\).

premise: The total change in velocity from t = 0 to t = 4 s is 6 m/s.
conclusion: The maximum velocity is reached when the total change in velocity is added to the initial velocity (which is 0 m/s since the body starts from rest).

premise: The maximum velocity is reached when the total change in velocity is added to the initial velocity.
conclusion: Thus, the maximum velocity is 6 m/s, which occurs at t = 4 s.
